Award.AwardTitle: Water Diffusion in Olivine: Experiments and Application to Phenocrysts
Award.AbstractNarration:
Measurements of water in the mineral olivine and its melt inclusions provide constraints on fundamental Earth processes such as the occurrence of plate tectonics, planetary melting, and volcanic explosivity. However, interpretations of these measurements are highly debated because of the possibility that water may exchange rapidly with the surrounding environment during transport from the earth's interior to the site of collection. The extent of this exchange depends on how fast water diffuses in olivine. Water diffusion in olivine can occur by several different mechanisms, some of which are orders of magnitude faster than others at the same temperature, resulting in considerable uncertainty about which diffusion rate to apply. This project aims to resolve that ambiguity while supporting an early-career female scientist; undergraduate students will also contribute to the investigation. The research results will be shared with the general public and the research community.

This project will include targeted dehydration experiments as well as measurements of natural samples to elucidate the role of different diffusion mechanisms as a function of oxygen fugacity, temperature, and time. Oriented single crystals of olivine will be first completely dehydrated and equilibrated at the temperature of interest, then fully hydrated at high pressure, and finally placed in a 1-atm gas-mixing furnace and heated in steps until fully dehydrated. After each step, infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) measurements will be taken along profiles in each dimension of the sample to quantify the internal water concentration and extent of diffusion. This approach takes advantage of a new numerical technique for interpreting infrared spectroscopic measurements through uncut crystal blocks, allowing for the first time a time-series of hydrogen diffusion data on the same sample in multiple orientations. These laboratory experiments will be complemented by FTIR measurements of various sized olivine phenocrysts from Fuego Volcano. This study will be the first attempt to identify and apply site-specific diffusivities in samples that are well-characterized for their degassing and ascent history.

POR.DRECONTENT:
It is still unclear what drives some volcanic eruptions to be more explosive than others. Theory and sparse data indicate that one key parameter is the magma ascent (decompression) rate in the conduit before the eruption. Like a soda bottle, volcanic eruptions are driven by gas bubbles trying to escape from liquid.  And like a soda bottle, the rate of decompression matters. Slowly opening the bottle cap causes a soda eruption to fizzle, just as magma ascending slowly may lose its gas peacefully, forestalling an explosive eruption.  It is thus critical to know how fast magma rises prior to eruption. One promising approach to timing the events prior to eruption involves the forensic study of volcanic crystals that erupt. Crystals that develop chemical zonation patterns have recently been developed as timekeepers, provided the diffusivity of the chemical species is known (see Crystal Clock figure). The purpose of this study was to determine the diffusivity of water in the mineral olivine, for use as a syn-eruptive crystal clock.

 

New developments in microbeam analysis are permitting measurement of water in tiny concentrations – parts per million – within volcanic olivine crystals, revealing profiles of water-loss from the crystal rim (see Olivine Zonation figure). These profiles record olivines leaking water as they strive to keep in equilibrium with exterior magma that is losing its water to bubbles as it ascends. The shape of the profile reflects the timescale for water loss, with steep profiles and narrow rims reflecting shorter times than wide rims. Currently published measurements of water diffusion in olivine are highly uncertain, however, permitting timescales that vary from seconds to hours for diffusion profiles on the order of 100 microns. Our work is providing new accurate diffusivities, appropriate to volcanic olivines for the first time. In the example provided for the eruption of the Kilauea Iki fire fountain in 1959 (see Olivine Zonation figure), the natural Iki olivine profiles reveal minutes of ascent prior to eruption, based on our new laboratory measurements that calibrate this crystal clock. With such an approach, each olivine crystal could potentially tell its story of ascent, and so test how the ascent rate relates to eruption explosivity.
